Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Bridging Reliability Analysis and Reality in Sensor Systems: Theories and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: From the viewpoint of researchers, developers, and even consumers, reliability analysis is recognized as an indispensable step before sensor network systems can be widely deployed for mission-critical applications. However, there is a big gap between traditional network reliability analysis theories and realistic sensor network system environments. The primary objective of this research is to close such gap through new metrics, analytical models, and approaches for the reliability analysis of large-scale sensor networks. Specifically, the research has three major components: 1) concepts, metrics, and models for describing the reliability behavior of sensor networks, 2) new algorithms and methodologies for efficient reliability evaluation of sensor networks, and 3) applications/case studies for demonstrating the practical significance of the proposed theoretical approaches. The new reliability theories and methodologies developed through this project are fundamental contributions to the body of knowledge on the network system reliability as well as to the design of reliable sensor systems. Additionally, a software tool and a prototype sensor system for railway monitoring will be built to validate the proposed research, and render the theoretical research operational and applicable. This project has broader impacts through graduate and undergraduate education, and through an integrated outreach and group mentoring program that will promote recruitment and retention of female students in engineering disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
(This is the collaborative research project. The partner is the Univ. of Mass, Dartmouth, award #1112947.)

Reliability analysis is an indispensable step before wireless sensor network (WSN) systems can be widely deployed for critical applications such as healthcare, military surveillance, and environmental monitoring. This project has produced new reliability metrics, models, and evaluation approaches, providing feasible and effective solutions for reliability analysis and design of large-scale WSNs in the real world.

Particularly, new metrics and models were developed for reliability analysis of WSNs under different communication paradigms and different data delivery models. The most reliable data delivery model was found. Furthermore, relationships between the reliability metrics and various network topology characteristics were identified.

Applications within a WSN involves both acquisition of sensed data about physical phenomena and reliable delivery of observed data from sensors to the sink node. This project yielded an innovative approach that evaluates the Application Communication Reliability (ACR) of WSNs considering both aspects, offering guidelines for the design and choice of WSN routing protocols.

Accurate system-level reliability evaluation replies on the accurate component-level reliability evaluation. This project generated results of the component importance analysis, which can assist in identifying system weakness, and thus in the WSN design, maintenance and improvement. As an example, a comprehensive cost function-based routing approach that integrates end-to-end path reliability, cost and energy consumption at component level was proposed for providing satisfactory quality of service to applications running on the hybrid WSN.

The reliability metrics, models, evaluation methods and routing algorithms developed in this project are fundamental contributions to the body of knowledge on the system reliability modeling and analysis, as well as to the design and operation of reliable sensor network systems. Some theoretical results were validated through experimental case studies on a WSN-based monitoring system testbed built using TelosB motes. A WSN reliability analysis software tool was developed, which renders the theoretical research operational and applicable.

 

This project also has a multidisciplinary component. It was discovered that the proposed metrics and methodologies in reliability analysis can yield innovative approaches that quantitatively evaluate privacy level in online social networks. The rapid growth of social network sites (SNS) has coincided with an increasing concern over personal data privacy. Most SNS allow users specify their privacy settings, but many users do not understand the consequence of these settings. This research utilized reliably analysis tools to develop a Trust?Aware Privacy Evaluation (TAPE) framework for privacy evaluation in online social networks. TAPE demonstrated the practical significance of the proposed theoretical approaches, as well as provided a unique solution to the SNS privacy level assessment problem.

This project provided research opportunities for one Ph.D. students in a way that substantially expands their analytical and computer simulation skills. This student was provided opportunities to present research results at conferences and university research forums. Research results and knowledge related to the project have been disseminated to the academic community and industry through 1 Ph.D. dissertations, 9 journal papers, and 9 conference papers. Lectures on the findings from this project were incorporated into two undergraduate courses. A half-day forum was organized for students who were interested in sensor network research to explore career options in Computer Engineering.
